question.title: Enums in Java: empty line with semicolon?
question.body:
Today I wanted to write a simple Java enum (using java 21) with a little help from my IntelliJ IDEA. Just a simple enum with one value.

This is what IntelliJ created for me:

public enum MySimpleEnum {
    ;
    public static final String Y = "Yes";
}

Can anyone explain what's happening here? Removing the empty line with semicolon breaks the code.

answers.body:
As per the spec, an enum is defined as

 { [EnumConstantList] [,] [EnumBodyDeclarations] }

Further EnumBodyDeclarations is defined as

; {ClassBodyDeclaration}

Notice the leading ;

Since the EnumConstantList (basically the part where you define the possible values for your enum) is not mandatory, your enum is created with only the EnumBodyDeclaration part and if you remove that ; you're introducing a syntax error.

Because you don't have any constants in your enum, IntelliJ IDEA created an empty constants section for you. According to the docs:

Java requires that the constants be defined first, prior to any fields or methods. Also, when there are fields and methods, the list of enum constants must end with a semicolon.

question_comments.body: You said you wanted "a simple enum with one value". Note that the value Y is not an enum constant. It is a static field. Although MySimpleEnum is declared as an enum, it contains no constants, so what you have is not much different from a final class with a private constructor.
